Is 'abundance' the new watchword of US Democrats?
subhead: Born in California, the concept of 'abundance' has captivated the centrist wing of the Democratic Party. It advocates for an interventionist state paired with deregulation to facilitate investment and increase the supply of essential goods such as housing, energy, transportation and healthcare.

Nigerian air force kills 35 militants in strikes near Cameroon border
subhead: Nigeria's military said Saturday its air force carried out precision strikes that killed more than 35 jihadist fighters massed near the Cameroon frontier, as the army faces a renewed wave of Boko Haram and ISWAP attacks in the northeast.

headline: Global South: Trump is playing into China's hands
subhead: The erratic tariff policy pursued by the US president and his administration has so far mainly served to strengthen ties between countries in the Global South with Beijing, and, where relevant, Moscow.

headline: Baidu, China's robotaxi leader, sets sights on Europe
subhead: The Chinese tech giant, in partnership with American company Lyft, aims to launch driverless ride-hailing services in Germany and the United Kingdom in 2026. While China and the US are driving the robotaxi revolution, Europe remains a bystander.

headline: Is French rap still political?
subhead: Far from the politically engaged artists of the 1990s, today's top rappers have built their success on largely depoliticized lyrics. Yet, through their stories, both established stars and amateur rappers still convey a strong sense of social engagement.

The mysteries of actress Isabelle Adjani's vocation
subhead: 'Adjani, The Famous Stranger' (1/6). Nothing seemed to predestine her to become one of the greatest stars of French cinema. Yet the young actress, born to an Algerian father and a German mother, experienced a meteoric rise. She made her debut on stage at barely 17 years old and quickly transitioned to film.

headline: Being a writer in the digital age? James Baldwin 'seemed free in ways we no longer can be'
subhead: 'Letters from America' (6/6). Writer and journalist Thomas Chatterton Williams envies the great American author's bohemian, technology-free existence, despite the chaos it represented.

headline: In 'Kolkhoze,' Emmanuel Carrère becomes his mother's son
subhead: In his new book, the French author reflects on his often tumultuous relationship with his late mother, Hélène Carrère d'Encausse, and explores what he owes her. This major work addresses themes of death, love and writing.
